Despite complicated processes, these methods only improve the overall responsivity and are not capable of wavelength selective enhancement. div.div:
The responsivities of MoS
2
based photodetectors or phototransistors have been improved by integrating additional layers or implementing a hetero-structure. Despite complicated processes, these methods only improve the overall responsivity and are not capable of wavelength selective enhancement. This study reports the wavelength-selective enhancement of photo-responsivity in a multi-layer MoS
2
phototransistor by employing a reflective Al metal gate. We have observed that the photo-responsivities are enhanced at a wavelength of ∼500 nm (FWHM = 140 nm) in the Al metal-gated multi-layer MoS
2
phototransistors. The finite difference time domain method also confirmed that the wavelength for enhanced responsivity can be adjusted according to the thicknesses of the MoS
2
and gate insulating layer. Using this effect, the Al metal-gated multi-layer MoS
2
phototransistors can be tuned for specific applications.

Two-dimensional materials such as graphene have attracted considerable attention in recent years due to their superior electrical properties.
1
1. F. Schwierz, “
Graphene transistors
,” Nat. Nanotechnol.
5
, 487–
496
(2010).
https://doi.org/10.1038/nnano.2010.89

To determine the switching characteristics, variation of drain current (

2
and Al

. When the MoS
2
is illuminated, the photo-generated holes are captured in the traps, thus breaking the neutrality of the MoS
2
channel. The positively charged MoS
2
attracts more electrons from the source to maintain the neutrality, and the number of induced electrons is mainly responsible for the photocurrent. Thus, the photo-switching time is proportional to the number of traps that capture and release carriers. The increase in the photo-response time with the incident light intensity means the increase in the trapped charge. Due to the limited number of traps, the response time eventually saturates at a certain optical power.

In order to understand the wavelength-selective responsivity enhancement, we have used FDTD (finite-difference time-domain) analysis. The active region, except the source and drain electrode, was modeled by a planar stack of the Al gate, Al
2
O
3
insulator, and MoS
2
. The source was incident on MoS
2
from the top, and the optical field was monitored in the MoS
2
layer to calculate the absorption. For simplicity, periodic boundary conditions are assumed in the in-plane direction, and a perfectly matched layer (PML) is employed in the vertical direction. Figure
4(b)
presents the absorption spectra of the MoS
2
layer in the Al-gated phototransistor, calculated as the thickness of the MoS
2
layer is varied. It is clear that the photoresponsivity is modified by the inherent absorption spectra of MoS
2
shown alongside in the figure. The resonance wavelength where the responsivity is enhanced increases as the thickness of the MoS
2
layer increases. We also have calculated the variation of absorption of the fixed 20 nm MoS
2
according to the Al
2
O
3
thickness as shown in Fig.
4(c)
. The resonant peak is shifted as the Al
2
O
3
thickness increases. Thus, it is found that the absorption peak wavelength is affected by the thicknesses of MoS
2
and Al
2
O
3
. This means that light is confined across MoS
2
and Al
2
O
3
that serve as cavities. When Al
2
O
3
is 120 nm thick, the calculated peak absorption showed good agreement with the measured one. This discrepancy in the Al
2
O
3
thickness is due to the fact that the thickness of the sol-gel processed Al
2
O
3
was estimated by measuring the other samples made under the same conditions by a surface profiler.

In summary, we have investigated the Al metal-gated multi-layer MoS
2
phototransistor in which the peak photo-responsivity wavelength can be controlled by thicknesses or MoS
2
. The Al metal-gated device exhibits similar electrical characteristics in mobility and subthreshold swing compared to the Si gated device. The increase in photocurrent with irradiance and the change in photo-responsivity and specific detectivity according to gate bias were also presented. As the gate voltage increases, the barriers between the MoS
2
and the source/drain contacts lower, contributing to the photocurrent increase. At the same time, however, the dark current also increases, and hence, the gate voltage above the threshold voltage drops the specific detectivity. The measured spectral responsivity reveals the enhanced photo-responsivity at a wavelength of ∼500 nm (FWHM = 140 nm). The enhanced photo-responsivity at a particular wavelength is due to the reflection of incident light at the metal gate helping the light confined across the gate insulator and the MoS
2
layer with different thicknesses. The finite difference time domain (FDTD) method was also performed to validate that the wavelength for enhanced responsivity can be adjusted according to the thicknesses of the MoS
2
. With this effect, for a specific application, the multi-layer MoS
2
phototransistor can be designed with controlled responsivity at a selected wavelength by varying the thickness of the MoS
2
layer.
